column1: Your child's spleen was removed after your child was given general anesthesia (asleep and pain-free).

Your child's activity restrictions will depend on: - The type of surgery (open or laparoscopic) - Your child's age - The reason for the operation Ask your doctor about specific activity instructions and limitations.
You can give your child acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain.
You may remove the incision dressings (bandages) to give your child a shower.
- Always tell your child's doctor if your child has a fever, sore throat, headache, belly pain, or diarrhea, or an injury that breaks the skin.

Ask your child's doctor if your child should have (or already had) these vaccines: - Pneumonia - Meningococcal - Haemophilus - Flu shot (every year) Your child may need to take antibiotics every day for a while.
These things will help prevent infections in your child: - Teach your child to wash his or her hands often with soap and water.
- Get your child treated for any bites, especially dog bites, right away.
- Tell all of your child's health care providers (dentist, doctors, nurses, or nurse practitioners) that your child does not have a spleen.
